title: Simchas Torah Commences This Evening At Sundown
text:
Photo credit: Yaakov Naumi / Flash90 
Dear Readers, 
Due to the Jewish holiday’s second days of Sukkos, which continues this evening at sundown, we will not be updating our website until Wednesday morning. 
During this joyful time, Jews celebrate finishing the reading of the entire Torah scribe, which is re-read at the beginning of the next cycle following the holidays. 
The holiday consists of joyfully dancing with the Torah. The whole community gathers in the synagogue to hold it for a few minutes, passing it around to each and every member. Community members are then called up to read the Torah — even youngsters under the age of 13 that never participate in community duties — are called up on their own to partake in the readings. The highlight of the festivities is the Kol HaNe’arim reading, which features children who cannot make the Bracha on their own for the Torah. Fathers take the children under a canopy and make the blessing together, all while reading for them. The community then blesses the children. 
JP Updates wishes you all a safe, joyful holiday. 
On Wednesday, we’ll be back to bringing you a daily round-up of news.
